Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2012 01:34PM - edited Oct 8, 2012 01:35PM by morningperson I have had bleeding issues; they were related to bone marrow suppression, anemia and the aspirin in the body wash. I doubt mine were related to anything breast cancer-related; this was three years ago and my bone marrow issues have gotten much better. Are you still having periods? If so, are they heavy? Another cause for the bleeding issue could be a liver problem. I do think you need to go to the doctor to get this checked out.
Posts.Title: Petechiae? MissAye MissAye

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2012 09:16AM - edited Oct 8, 2012 09:18AM by morningperson Hi, I am not a medical professional, but you might consider going to the doc for some blood work; you might have something as simple as a vitamin c deficiency. Other things that might cause the bleeding under the skin are blood thinning medication, excess vitamin E, fish oil, ginko biloba, vitamin k deficiency, anemia, drug reaction, aspirin, nsaids, and lots of other supplements. A few years ago, I noticed that I was bruising and bleeding profusely from any little cut, and my menstrual periods were horrendous. After looking at all my supplements, I realized that the body scrub I was using had 2% salicylate-which is aspirin! I used so much on my skin, that a lot got absorbed and was causing the blood clotting issues! So, the bleeding under the skin can be caused by something very simple and easy to correct. Here's an article on blood-thinning supplements and foods: http://www.livestrong.com/article/484181-herbs-minerals-vitamins-that-reduce-blood-clotting/

Posts.Title: Got a problem...how long can I wait? autism_mom Paintingmywaythru

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2012 08:55AM - edited Sep 1, 2012 08:56AM by morningperson Hi, my mammogram is Tuesday at 9am. One thing that I've really held onto during this waiting process is to really "own" the phrase, "it's not cancer until they say it is." It might be cancer, it might not; my lump is fairly large and I have armpit involvement too, but I'm not going to accept cancer until I absolutely have to. I know this is outright denial; but don't knock it as a coping mechanism.  I've also taken long walks when possible; taken yoga class every day this week, and really just tried to live my life as if the lump doesn't exist. I also try to thing of the ladies on this forum who have been where we are, sometimes several times; for me it helps to know we are not alone. I have an 8 year-old son; I know exactly how you feel. Hope this helps even a little bit.

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2012 12:46PM morningperson wrote: Mammograms can be very useful, but I think a lot of people place too much faith in them. My lump is simply in an area where it cannot be manipulated in between plates plates, therefore it's not caught on mammogram. And excellent point, Wallycat; there are several types of cancer that do not show up well on mammogram or ultrasound; ILC is one of those types of CA; when it does show up, it can mimic a benign mass. Even if they say it's a cyst, I am going to try to get it removed and biopsied, even if I have to pay out of pocket to do so.

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2012 01:25PM morningperson wrote: Good luck with the MRI results; remember, more false positives with MRI, so even if the news comes back not good a biopsy could still come back benign. Mine is 8mm oval with indistinct margins, birads 3; the breast surgeon said the mass looked benign but he would biopsy if I wanted to, or we could wait three months and do another ultrasound. I chose to wait three months but may change my mind; my husband is really pushing me to biopsy now.
Posts.Title: Mammo clear, mass found on ultrasound morningperson morningperson

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2012 02:33PM morningperson wrote: Why don't you call and ask for a biopsy rather than MRI? The doc might be hesitant to biopsy because of the implants, but if you specifically ask, she/he might either consider it or at least tell you why mri was chosen before biopsy. BTW, if she/he doesn't tell you why, then ask. One thing I've learned from the ladies on this board and personal experience is that you've really got to ask for, and sometimes demand, answers. Again, good luck; please stay in touch; I'll be wanting to hear about your results.

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2012 02:40AM - edited Oct 6, 2012 02:40AM by morningperson Thank you all for the helpful information. My paternal family is small; my uncle had one biological daughter and she died in her 30's from a drug overdose. No known cancers. My father died in his early 50's from heart disease. My uncle is still alive; I do not know if he has had any type of cancer; I've just made contact with him after many years. My sister has has not had any known cancers, although she is a walking train-wreck health-wise. So, my brca risk is extremely small; but I think it was well worth thinking through the family history. Good thing I've stayed thin, fit, and sober; in my family the genetics for heart disease and substance abuse are much more concerning than risk for inheriting brca's, lol.
